The learner could well discover that none of the symmetries in the space hold. @KordingLab @GaryMarcus @GhaffariMaani @ylecun @yudapearl @scac1041 @PhilDawid @StephenPiment @AlexTensor @gopnik @stephensenn We tell them the space of possible symmetries (e.g., affine); the algorithm discovers which (e.g., translation, or some translations).

@GaryMarcus @GhaffariMaani @KordingLab @ylecun @yudapearl @scac1041 @PhilDawid @StephenPiment @AlexTensor @gopnik @stephensenn The prior is that there's a space of symmetries the phenomenon being modeled may obey (e.g., affine), and the learning task is to discover which (e.g., only translations, or only some translations).

@KordingLab @yudapearl @scac1041 @PhilDawid @GaryMarcus @StephenPiment @ylecun @AlexTensor @gopnik @stephensenn All rung 3 requires is a model that lets you condition on arbitrary evidence, including counterfactuals. @yudapearl @ylecun @aminkarbasi @AlexTensor @KordingLab @GaryMarcus Inductive bias is any knowledge or assumptions that you have prior to seeing the data. @ylecun @SaavedraReisson @mohammadalyoune What you're doing is like arguing a billion years ago that bacteria were the apex of evolution. @ylecun @SaavedraReisson @mohammadalyoune To paraphrase Ulam, using a term like "gradient-free optimization" is like referring to the bulk of zoology as the study of trunk-free animals. @erikbryn No! Uncertainty about the effects of GHGs is very high, but we can cap the upper tail risk by geoengineering, so overall increasing uncertainty decreases the expected utility of decarbonization.

Statistics: Difference btwn correct answer & average one.
